He said: A sheep for a sheep. So the Messenger of Allah ﷺ threw him. Abu Rukana said: Wrestle me again. So he wrestled him and the Messenger of Allah ﷺ threw him again. He said: Wrestle me once more. So he wrestled him and the Messenger of Allah ﷺ threw him again. Abu Rukana said: This is what I will tell my family - one sheep was eaten by a wolf, another was broken, so what will I say about the third? The Prophet ﷺ said: We would not gather against you by throwing you and fining you. Take your sheep.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from al-Zuhri from Urwah from Aisha: The wives of the Prophet ﷺ gathered, and they sent Fatimah to the Prophet ﷺ. They said to her: Say to him: Your wives have gathered together and are invoking you for justice regarding the daughter of Abu Quhafah. She said: I entered upon the Prophet ﷺ while he was with Aisha in her wrapper. I said to him: Your wives sent me to you and they are invoking you for justice regarding the daughter of Abu Quhafah. The Prophet ﷺ said to her: Do you love me? She said: Yes. He said: Then love her. Then I returned to them and informed them what the Prophet ﷺ said. They said: You have not done anything. Go back to him. Fatimah said: By Allah, I will never return to him about this again. Al-Zuhri said: And she was truly the daughter of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. They sent Zaynab bint Jahsh. Aisha said: And she was the one who rivaled me among the wives of the Prophet ﷺ. She came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: Your wives sent me to you and they are invoking you for justice regarding the daughter of Abu Quhafah. Then she turned upon me and cursed me. Then I began to watch the Prophet ﷺ and look towards him, whether he would permit me to defend myself from her. Then he remained silent, so she cursed me until I thought he did not hate me defending myself from her. So I confronted her and quickly silenced her. The Prophet ﷺ said to her: She is the daughter of Abu Bakr. Aisha said: I have not seen a woman better, more charitable, and more maintaining of family ties, and more giving of herself in everything seeking nearness to Allah than Zaynab, except for a moment of pride from jealousy that passes from her.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from al-Zuhri: I was with al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik when he mentioned Aisha (in a negative way). I said to him: O Commander of the Faithful, shall I tell you about a man from the people of the Levant to whom wisdom was given? He said: Who is he? I said: He is Abu Muslim al-Khawlani. And when the people of the Levant heard that they were mentioning Aisha, he said: I will inform you of your example and the example of your mother, like the example of two eyes in the head that harm their owner, and he cannot punish them except with that which is better for them. Then he remained silent. Al-Zuhri said: Abu Idris informed me of this from Abu Muslim al-Khawlani.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from Asim from Abdullah ibn Serjis: When the Prophet ﷺ traveled, he would say: O Allah, I seek refuge in you from the hardship of travel, from the sadness of returning home, from turning back after (being) set forward, and from seeing evil in family and wealth. When we asked Abd al-Razzaq about the meaning of 'turning back after being set forward', he said: I heard Mu'ammar saying it is 'calamity'. When we asked what calamity is, he said: It is a man who is righteous then turns and becomes a wicked person.
